X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=70936284

 
Dear Cantera users,

I am simulating stagnation-point flames.  I have run=
 across what I
believe to be an inconsistency in the specification of time-=
stepping and
steady-state tolerances.  From my understanding, the time-step=
ping
tolerances should only control the time-stepping portion of the solver=
,
while the steady-state tolerances will determine the accuracy of the
solu=
tion with the Newton solver.  However, if I run the simulation
twice, chang=
ing only the time-stepping tolerances, I end up with a
different steady-sta=
te solution.  The case with the "looser"
time-stepping tolerances converges=
 much quicker.  If I do the same
thing, but change only the steady-state to=
lerances, the final solutions
are the same and the solution takes basically=
 the same time.  

From these tests, I think that all tolerances in the pro=
blem are being
set equal to the time-stepping tolerances, and specifying th=
e
steady-state tolerances has no effect.  I am running the simulations
usin=
g python.  I have followed the path of the f.set(tol =3D tol_ss,
tol_time =
=3D tol_ts) command from StagnationFlow.py through onedim.py to
Domain1D.h.=
  However, I cannot see where the source of the problem is.

It appears to =
be a more general problem than the StagnationFlow class
and could affect al=
l one-dimensional simulations.

Any help on this would be greatly appreciat=
ed.

Happy New Year,

Jeffrey M. Bergthorson
Postdoctoral Scholar in Aerona=
utics
California Institute of Technology
Pasadena, CA, 91106
626.395.4445 (=
phone)
